item.title: DOOM: The Dark Ages Fans Discover Unused Weapon Through Console Commands
item.description:
Summary

  • DOOM: The Dark Ages features new weapons like the spike-launching Shredder and savage Skullcrusher.
  • Fans have discovered an unused weapon in DOOM: The Dark Ages, possibly related to the Chainshot.
  • Speculation suggests the unused weapon could play a role in future DLC set in the mysterious Cosmic Realm.

Players are treated to a wide expanse of punchy new weapons in DOOM: The Dark Ages , but some fans have recently discovered the existence of a strange, unused weapon that some theorize would have been the counterpart to the Chainshot. This curious gun in DOOM: The Dark Ages isn't the first unused weapon that fans have found in the legendary FPS franchise, and some speculate that it could actually play a part in The Dark Ages ' future DLC.

Guns have always been a crucial component of DOOM 's identity, and DOOM: The Dark Ages doesn't disappoint with its new additions to the Slayer's arsenal. Returning classics such as the plasma gun and the Slayer's iconic Super Shotgun are, of course, back in the mix, but traditional weapon archetypes such as the machine gun have been somewhat reimagined. In DOOM: The Dark Ages , players can wield the spike-launching Shredder as their first fully-automatic weapon, and can even get their hands on the more savage Skullcrusher later on, which spits shards of demon bone over a wide area at a high rate of fire. DOOM: The Dark Ages also arms players with a couple of powerful melee weapons, including the flail and devastatingly powerful Dreadmace.

While most weapon classes in DOOM: The Dark Ages each contain two different guns — similarly to how each weapon in other DOOM titles features two swapable mods — the Reaver Chainshot appears to be an exception. While it has no official counterpart in the game currently, some fans believe that an unused weapon discovered thanks to console commands would have been the second Reaver weapon class. This strange weapon was recently shown off in an online clip shared by the user Naive_Lab_5189, and demonstrates the fully automatic weapon in action. Although fans will first need to utilize mods to take full advantage of DOOM: The Dark Ages ' console commands, the "give all" command allows players to try the gun out themselves.

This Unused DOOM: The Dark Ages Weapon Could Be A Taste Of What's To Come

Complete with what seems like an incomplete model and animation set, this weapon seems like it could be related to the Chainshot due to it also using metallic spheres as ammunition. Additionally, based on its similar appearance and design, the weapon looks like it could have its origins within the Cosmic Realm, the weird eldritch dimension introduced in DOOM: The Dark Ages . Some fans have speculated that this unused gun could be an experimental feature that's set to play a role in the game's future campaign DLC.

There's currently no real information regarding DOOM: The Dark Ages ' DLC besides the fact that it's on its way, but with the title being a prequel that's set during a critical time period in the DOOM universe, there are possibilities aplenty. With fans full of questions regarding the mysterious Cosmic Realm, it seems likely that the game's future DLC will have a focus on this new location somehow, and the addition of another creepy eldritch weapon would be perfectly fitting.

5 Images
5 Images

item.title: The Witcher 3: Best Ways To Get Red Mutagens
item.description:
Summary

  • Farm Nekkers for red mutagens early on in Velen, White Orchard, and more.
  • Hunt Arachas for red mutagens east of Heddel to boost your character.
  • Spend time in Toussaint for higher-level loot and red mutagens.

The key to success in The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is grabbing powerful mutagens to buff Geralt's abilities and build. The better the mutagen, the better the buff. The problem is, particularly for red mutagens, getting powerful versions is rare, and there's an element of luck involved with how powerful a mutagen is.

Luckily, for players looking to figure out an aggressive red mutagen build, there are a couple of brilliant ways to get mutagens fast. Usually, these involve specific monster farms, but there are a few areas and best practices to bear in mind, too.

1 Nekkers

Little Goblin Guys

Nekkers are one of the most annoying monsters in the game. On their own, they're easy, but a big group of them can make life miserable, particularly with their jumping attacks. However, they're worth hunting because they're a great source of red mutagens in the early game, and they make for some of the easier monster nests to deal with.

Nekkers can be found all over Velen, White Orchard, Skellige, Toussaint, and even Kaer Morhen valley, so they're easily the most readily available source. If hunting red mutagens is the name of the game, then hop off Roach anytime nekkers are spotted on the road to get started farming.

2 Arachas

Flower Crab Spiders

In the early game, arachasae are some of the biggest threats with tough shields and resistances to many basic signs, requiring some specific strategies to succeed. However, that toughness comes with proportionally great rewards, including red mutagens as one of the main drops.

The best place to find an Arachas farm is just east of Heddel, near the very east side of the main map, beside a hidden treasure. Simply kill the three arachas, pick up the drops, meditate for about a day, then return to continue the farming.

3 Cockatrice

Temu Dragon

The great thing about The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is the variety of monsters. Where most games would settle for a garden variety dragon, there's a whole range of flying beasties to take down, with the cockatrice being one of the strangest, but most fierce.

There are also some reliable spawn points for Cockatrices that every red mutagen farmer should know. Just north-east of Novigrad, west of Yantra, is one of the most reliable spawns in the game. Kill the beast, get lost, and continue the cycle until players have as many red mutagens as they need.

4 Giant Centipede

Creepy Crawly

Giant centipedes are really annoying in The Witcher 3 . Their burrowing attacks make them entirely immune to damage, and if Geralt can't close in fast, they'll just escape again. For some time, players thought this monster from the original The Witcher wouldn't return, but the Blood & Wine DLC saw it make a comeback.

Though they're annoying to fight, they're also excellent sources of red mutagens and acid extract. Hunt out monster nests throughout Toussaint to find loads of the creepy crawlies, and cut them down to get a fairly reliable source of red mutagens.

5 Prioritize Time In Toussaint

Dip In The French Quarter

Not only is Toussaint drop-dead stunning, but it's the best place to go for higher-level loot, considering it's meant predominantly for the end-game. By this point, builds might already be set up, but if a player's looking for more red mutagens, Toussaint is a great place to go.

That's not only because it plays host to great red mutagen droppers like giant centipedes, but also because the higher-level enemies simply mean bigger, beefier drops. To get the best variants of red mutagens, players should spend as much time as possible in this idyllic French-inspired paradise.

6 Dead Drowned

Dangerous Drowners

Not only are the Dead Drowned some of the most common enemies in the game, but they're also one of the best sources for general alchemical ingredients. They drop plenty of monster parts, general riff-raff, and most importantly of all, red mutagens.

It's easy to farm them, too. One of the best places is around the coast of Skellige, particularly the coast between Whale Graveyard and Redgill. Run down the coast, killing everything in sight, then meditate to reset the monster spawns. Works like a charm, every time. If players don't want to farm, they also appear in a lot of side quests.

7 Craft Red Mutagens

Artificial Solutions

When The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt was first released, the only method of getting very useful mutagens was finding them in drops, which could get pretty frustrating, particularly with red mutagens, which have a notoriously low drop rate.

Luckily, after the release of the Blood and Wine DLC, there's a merchant in Hauteville that sells recipes for making mutagens on the fly. While they need some rare ingredients, it's so much easier than farming, so this should be a top priority as soon as the hunt for red mutagens begins.

item.title: Baldur's Gate 3: 8 Best Mods That Add More Romance Options, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Mods for Baldur's Gate 3 enhance romance elements, including more reactive companions and appearance customization.
  • Enjoy additional hugs, kisses, and replayable romance scenes with various companions to spice up Tav's romantic life.
  • Use mods like 'Approval Cheat' to ensure higher approval rates from companions, leading to smoother romance progression.

Baldur’s Gate 3 continues to have a high player rate even after being officially out for over a year now, and this is because of the complex and immersive storylines, as well as a little bit of romance thrown in for good measure. Baldur’s Gate 3 would not be the same without the ability to romance some of the companions, especially as some of the storylines change because of it. Maybe the villains can get some time too.

Romance and Baldur’s Gate 3 go hand in hand, so it’s no surprise that modders have added some additional features to make romance easier, allowing for new options and more. Here are some of the best mods out there to up the romance game.

8 More Reactive Companions

Added Immersive Experience

  • More Reactive Companions Mod Link
  • Adds Unused Lines
  • Helps Playthrough Feel More Alive
  • More Tension (Flirtation?) Into Scenes

If players enjoy playing as Tav and want to hear more from the companions and what they think of each other (yes, even the flirtations), this is the mod for them. It repurposes all of the dialogue that is traditionally locked behind playthroughs playing as particular companions and brings them into the main Tav playthrough.

It makes party situations feel more alive, which is perfect when players are looking to get to know characters better before romancing them — or seeing what they really feel for each other. The lines match up with the scenarios in the game as they happen, so it is a perfect addition to a Tav playthrough with more immersion.

7 Appearance Edit Enhanced

Change It Up

  • Appearance Edit Enhanced Mod Link
  • Customize Companion Appearance
  • Great For Storytelling
  • Change Mid Playthrough

If players are looking to add a stylish layer to their playthroughs, this mod allows players to customize the look of any companion at any time in camp. This is perfect if players are looking to add more realism and changes as the game progresses. Love can change people, so surely it could change their appearance too.

Maybe players also just want to see their favorite companion with a new hairstyle in cutscenes, or prove to themselves that they would still love them if they were bald.

6 Party Limit Begone

More Companions, More Romance

  • Party Limit Begone Mod Link
  • 16 Members At Once
  • More Party Dynamics
  • Increases Companion Approval Exposure

This mod is the ultimate pick for many reasons, but it actually can help players romance characters too. With the option to add more people to the party and not leave any in the camp, when a player makes a decision and all party members are witness to it, they will all approve or disapprove more often, allowing romances to blossom much more easily.

With room for 16 total party members (and eight in multiplayer), that means more companions can be by the player's side through storylines, ensuring cutscenes and dialogues are seen by more companions, making the experience more immersive and interesting.

5 Hugs

A Comfort Break

  • Hugs Mod Link
  • Hug Any Party Member
  • Use Via Spell
  • Storytelling Element

Players sometimes just need a hug from their favorite companion so that they know that everything is going to be okay. With this mod, your Tav learns a spell that can be cast on any character in your party, and even those you have in camp.

The hugs can be great for storytelling progression, and while they do not do anything to up romance levels with characters, they can be a nice screenshot scene when you finally do get companions to open up to you about their life and/or feelings for you.

4 Kisses

Spice Up Your Tav Life

  • Kisses Mod Link
  • Kiss Any Party Member
  • Use Via Spell
  • Storytelling Element

This mod is the next stage up from the hugs mod and allows Tavs to cast a spell that gets companions to kiss them. While there are plenty of cutscenes for players to enjoy, sometimes a kiss is needed for some casual story progression with their Tav lore, or maybe it’s just wanted instead.

There are different options for different body types and tallness, ensuring that no kiss is awkward; perfect for showing to friends that your companion really is your one and only.

3 Approval Cheat

Never Get Rejected

  • Approval Cheat Mod Link
  • Make Everyone Happy
  • Use Via Keys
  • Higher Approval Rates Faster

Sometimes, players can’t please companions with their choices no matter what they do. And when you are looking to romance them as soon as possible, a mod can help players make that happen anyway. The approval cheat allows players to increase or decrease approval from companions automatically.

These come in the form of keys and can be used in increments of 15. With a higher approval rate from companions, players will learn more about them, and this can then turn into the blossoming romance they might be looking for.

2 Replayable Romance Scenes

Romantic Cutscenes Again and Again

  • Replayable Romance Scenes Mod Link
  • Replay Cutscenes With Anyone
  • Experiment With Location
  • Use With Spell

Seeing a cutscene once may not be enough, and this mod is for players looking to experience the magic over and over again — or maybe even see it through another companion’s eyes. This mod comes in the shape of a spell that can be cast on companions, NPCs, or even inanimate objects.

All the scenes will play in a different location dependent on the last camp visited, which means replaying the cutscenes will look different as players progress through the story. For all the romantics out there, this mod is the perfect way to see those special scenes whenever they want to.

1 No Romance Limit

Romance Every Companion

  • No Romance Limit Mod Link
  • No Limit On Romance
  • No Awkward Breakups
  • No Linear Path

This mod has to take the top spot because it allows players to romance any number of companions without getting dumped. It can be disheartening when you have to choose one path in the road of romance, so this mod removes the need to be sad. Players can romance all the characters they like and see all the cutscenes with characters in one playthrough if they would like to.

With no limit, players can focus on making sure that their favorite companions become their partner before the third act; otherwise, those they are just ‘dating’ will break up with them before the story continues.

item.title: When to Do Gates in Oblivion Remastered
item.description:
Summary

  • Players can choose when to close Oblivion Gates in Oblivion Remastered.
  • Kvatch's Oblivion Gate becomes harder after level 10 due to leveled enemies.
  • Level 17+ yields the best Sigil Stones; Gates are finite & tied to the world state.

Closing Oblivion Gates is a core activity in The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered , central to the overarching storyline and the main mission. However, thanks to the longstanding tradition of Elder Scrolls games giving fans complete freedom in where they want to go and what they want to do, the exact time and level at which players attempt Oblivion Gates is entirely up to them. Ignoring the main story in Oblivion Remastered in favor of exploration and side quests is not only possible, but somewhat expected.

That said, there are downsides to ignoring the Oblivion Gates for too long or closing them too early, something that Oblivion Remastered doesn't come out and say. While technically, there is nothing preventing players from playing at their own pace, there is an optimal and a sub-optimal way of doing things, and this includes Gates.

Kvatch's Oblivion Gate is a Unique Case

After Level 10, Kvatch's Oblivion Gate Becomes Extremely Difficult

"Find the Heir" is an early-game mission that doubles as a tutorial on how to close Oblivion Gates. After players deliver the Amulet of Kings to Jauffre, they are tasked with finding Martin, Uriel Septim's last living heir, who has become a priest in Weynon Priory near Kvatch, where the first Oblivion Gate spawns. While it is possible to delay this mission indefinitely, it's best to complete "Find the Heir" and the subsequent mission "The Siege of Kvatch" as early as possible.

The reason behind it is simple—enemies in Oblivion Remastered are leveled, which means the higher the level of a character, the stronger the enemies they face. In the case of Kvatch's Oblivion Gate, if a character is level 1-4, they will face extremely weak Daedra that are easy to handle. However, at level 10+, these weak Daedra are replaced by high-level variants like Flame Atronachs, Dremora Lords, and Daedroths.

The problem with this is that if the player used tricks or glitches to level their character in Oblivion Remastered , like power-leveling a non-combat skill to 100 using exploits, their level does not represent their actual combat strength. In the "Siege of Kvatch," this issue is further amplified because the number of Daedra that need to be defeated is balanced around a small army of humans facing off against them. However, at level 10+, these Daedra can easily 1-shot almost all human followers, skewing the difficulty.

Sigil Stones From Oblivion Gates are Leveled

Level 17+ Oblivion Gates Yield the Best Rewards

Closing an Oblivion Gate involves climbing to the top of a tower and closing the "eye" of Oblivion. The reward for doing so is a Sigil Stone, a unique material that can be used to enchant weapons and armor in Oblivion Remastered . Like enemies, Sigil Stones are also leveled; the higher the level of a character closing the eye of Oblivion, the better the Sigil Stone will be.

There are five tiers of Sigil Stones: Descendent, Subjacent, Latent, Ascendant, and Transcendent, with Transcendent being the highest. Any Oblivion Gate that is closed by a character who is level 17 or above will drop a Transcendent Sigil Stone. If the same Gate is closed by a Level 16 character, it will be an Ascendant Sigil Stone instead. For maximum gain, it's advisable that players wait until they are level 17 before seriously clearing all Oblivion Gates scattered across the map.

Oblivion Gates Spawns are Tied to the World State

The number of Oblivion Gates in the world is finite—a maximum of 60, and once all of them are closed, they will not reopen. Additionally, the world state dictates how many of the 60 possible Gates are present. The easy solution is to progress the story until Martin asks for a Daedric Artifact, during the main quest "Blood of the Daedra." Then, scour the map for all Oblivion Gates in the wilderness and close them. There are 80 possible locations where an Oblivion Gate can spawn, which means quite a bit of exploration is required to find all of them.

After the final quest of Oblivion Remastered is completed and the main story is finished, all Oblivion Gates on the map will automatically close, locking all progress. If this happens, other than reloading an earlier save, there is no way to respawn the closed Oblivion Gates or obtain any rewards from them.

6 Images
6 Images

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion™ Remastered modernizes the 2006 Game of the Year with all new stunning visuals and refined gameplay. Explore the vast landscape of Cyrodiil like never before and stop the forces of Oblivion from overtaking the land in one of the greatest RPGs ever from the award-winning Bethesda Game Studios.

Rediscover Cyrodiil
Journey through the rich world of Tamriel and battle across the planes of Oblivion where handcrafted details have been meticulously recreated to ensure each moment of exploration is awe-inspiring.

Navigate Your Own Story
From the noble warrior to the sinister assassin, wizened sorcerer, or scrappy blacksmith, forge your path and play the way you want.

Experience an Epic Adventure
Step inside a universe bursting with captivating stories and encounter an unforgettable cast of characters. Master swordcraft and wield powerful magic as you fight to save Tamriel from the Daedric invasion.

The Complete Story
Experience everything Oblivion has to offer with previously released story expansions Shivering Isles, Knights of the Nine, and additional downloadable content included in The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered.

item.title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 Given as Gift to Czech Prime Minister
item.description:
Summary

  • Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala received Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 Collector's Edition as a gift during a government visit.
  • The developers at Warhorse Studios are grateful that the game is being recognized at a government level and in Czech society.
  • New content and expansions are planned for Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, with Fiala among players to receive expansions at no additional cost.

Czech Republic Prime Minister Petr Fiala recently received a Collector's Edition copy of Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 as a gift during a recent government visit. Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 was released back on February 4 and takes place in 15th-century Bohemia, the historical land where the Czech Republic is now in the 21st century.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 is Warhorse Studios' latest success story, with over three million copies since the game's launch. The game's refined combat system and expansive medieval world earned it critical acclaim and glowing reception from fans. In addition, developer Warhorse Studios promised that new content and features would be added to Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 in various post-launch updates. Most recently, Warhorse Studios released Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 update 1.3 on May 15 alongside the Brushes with Death DLC, which is one of three expansions planned for the game throughout 2025. The DLC can be bought separately on digital storefronts or as part of the Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 Expansion Pass. The Expansion Pass gives players access to all three expansions as they are released, and those who purchase the Collector's Edition have an Expansion Pass voucher to claim.

The official Warhorse Studios Twitter account shared photos of Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala's visit to the town of Kuttenberg, where mayor Lukáš Seifert surprised him with a copy of Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 Collector's Edition as a gift. The developers at Warhorse Studios are proud to see their game presented as a gift, and they're grateful that Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 receives support and recognition in Czech society. As shown in the photos, the Czech Prime Minister was very happy to receive the gift, with Warhorse Studios noting that the Prime Minister's team burst into jealous applause.

Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala Receives Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 Collector's Edition as a Gift

Although many fans on Twitter are happy that Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 is being acknowledged at the government level in the Czech Republic, others aren't too pleased. There are players wanting Warhorse Studios to focus on fixing strange flickering issues affecting Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 after the release of update 1.3. Although there are some workarounds for the flickering issues in the PC version through console commands, console players on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S don't have access to this feature.

At the very least, Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 looks set to break more sales records in the near future, and there is new content coming in the form of the two new expansions. Moreover, Warhorse Studios Prime Minister Fiala is among one of the many players that will have access to these expansions to see how Henry's story in Bohemia evolves further. Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2's future updates could bring fan-requested features and more bug fixes as well.
